title: prime minister tory leader odds news
story: We take a look at the latest odds on remaining couple of contenders, Boris Johnson and Jeremy Hunt, who will face the vote of the Conservative Party membership.The first to go was Sam Gyimah, who backed down on June  after failing to get the necessary eight MP backers to enter the race.Housing minister Kit Malthouse and Brexit Secretary James Cleverly announced they would run but withdrew shortly before nominations closed.There were then  candidates going into the first round vote on June  - but four dropped by the wayside within  hours.Andrea Leadsom, Esther McVey and Mark Harper were eliminated after failing to achieve the requisite  Tory MPs to get them past the first round.Health secretary Matt Hancock, who had  backers, withdrew hours later on June  after realising he could not win the race.In yesterday’s third knockout ballot, soft Brexiteer Mr Stewart came last by some way — shedding ten votes to end up with just .Boris Johnson, Jeremy Hunt, Michael Gove and Sajid Javid faced another round of voting with Javid being dumped.Finally, Gove was hoofed out yesterday with leaving just BoJo and Hunt to face to Tory faithful in the final ballot.Boris Johnson remains the runaway favourite to be the next prime minister.Here are what the bookies are saying on June , , according to Paddy Power.Former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson is still a hugely popular figure among Tory grassroots and the general public.Boris quit as Foreign Secretary in July , just hours after she lost Brexit Secretary David Davis over her Chequers plan to keep close ties to Brussels.He called on May to stop dithering and tell the EU that Britain will not accept the controversial backstop arrangement designed to avoid a hard border in Ireland.The -year-old also pledged to pay for a massive tax break for million Brits through money reserved for a No Deal exit - despite being open to a No Deal.He began his campaign a little later than the other candidates on June , in a bid perhaps to steal some of their thunder.He vowed to deliver super-fast Brexit.Mr Hunt was the longest-serving Health Secretary in British historybefore replacing Boris as Foreign Secretary.He left the Department of Health after securing a £bn funding increase for the NHS, but was hated by junior doctors after changing their contracts so they wouldnt receive extra pay for the many shts they work - previously classied as unsociable hours.Despite campaigning for Remain during the referendum, Hunt now backs the UKs withdrawal from the EU.Just hours after Mrs May resigned, he put his name into the hat to be in the running to replace her.On June , Trade Secretary Liam Fox threw his support behind Hunt in a surprise move, followed by two heavyweights - prominent leaver and defence secretary Penny Mordaunt and work and pensions secretary Amber Rudd.Hunt opened his leadership bid by claiming the new PM might not be able to start renegotiating with the EU until November  because its new Commission only starts then.Theresa May stepped down as Tory leader without delivering Brexit and with her party on the verge of extinction.May claimed she had done all she could to take Britain out of the EU with a deal, saying: Ever since I first stepped through the door behind me as Prime Minister, I have striven to make the United Kingdom a country that works not just for a privileged few, but for everyone. And to honour the result of the EU referendum.If you give people a choice you have a duty to implement what they decide. I have done my best to do that.Sadly I have not been able to do so. I tried three times - I believe it was right to persevere even when the odds against success seemed high.May survived a vote of no confidence in December , but repeated thwarted attempts to pass her Brexit deal left her without authority.May will remain as Prime Minister until a new party leader is announced in the week beginning July .

title: tory leadership race candidate brexit views
story: Below, we take a look at whos still in the running - andfar-away favourite Boris Johnson could go all the way.The former Foreign Secretary quit his role because he disagreed with Theresa Mays plan for Brexit and is currently the bookies favourite to win the leadership contest.Boris Johnson was at the helm of the Vote Leave campaign back in  and nearly beat the current PM to the role after Cameron resigned.Since the referendum the -year-old has been brandishing his leave credentials. In a speech in Switzerland he vowed to take Britain out of the EU with a deal or no deal come October he gets chosen.Johnson said he would hold the EU to ransom and refuse to pay the £billion orce bill unless they agree to more favourable terms for Brexit.He also vowed to slash income tax for three million Brits.He said: Our friends and partners need to understand that the money is going to be retained until such time as we have greater clarity about the way forward.I always thought it was extraordinary that we should agree to write that entire cheque before having a final deal. In getting a good deal, money is a great solvent and a great lubricant.Johnson comfortably topped the poll from the first round of voting, securing  votes from his colleagues.This is well above the  needed to guarantee his place in the final two, making him a firm favourite as it stands.But supporters were reminded that only once in the history of the Conservative party has the favourite ever been elected.The Foreign Secretary who campaigned for Remain in the  referendum is the second favourite for leader.Jeremy Hunt claims his business background would help him negotiate a good deal with Brussels as doing deals is my bread and butter as someone who has set up their own business.The -year-old said he would back a No Deal Brexit with a heavy heartit was the only option left.Hunt has said he wants to slash corporation tax to boost businesses.On June  he claimed Germany’s Angela Merkel COULD renegotiate Brexit with a new Tory PM.He has the backing of Amber Rudd.While in second place after the first round vote, Hunt is trailing far behind Johnson with only just over a third of his share.But Amber Rudd, who is backing Hunt, said he came a good second and was delighted with the result.The Environment Secretary announced his bid to be the next Prime Minister on June .Michael Gove has said he is willing to delay Brexit for as long as needed to ensure a deal is agreed rather than just crashing out on October .He is posing as a unying candidate and said: I believe that Im ready to unite the Conservative and Unionist Party, ready to deliver Brexit, and ready to lead this great country.Gove notably defended Theresa Mays Brexit deal in the House of Commons.However, his chances may have been dented by his cocaine admission.After the first round, Gove came a close third after Hunt and Johnson with  votes.The Home Secretary announced his candidacy in a video on Twitter and was one of the Remain campaigners in .Sajid Javid, , has said his party must get on and deliver Brexit but has positioned himself as a firm Remainer.But speaking to Sophy Ridge on Sunday he said: The policy of any government I lead will be to leave on  October. We will do everything in our power to leave on  October.I will do everything I can to get a deal, butI have to choose between no deal and no Brexit, I will choose no deal.If elected the Bromsgrove MP would be the UKs first Prime Minister from an ethnic minority.He has pledged to end austerity and pump billions into education.Scottish Conservatives leader Ruth Davidson has given him her support.It is thought defeated Andrea Leadsom could back Sajid Javid after he secured  votes in the first round.In a moving message the Home Secretary insisted he was ideally placed to lead a Conservative Government that would aim to bring people from all sides together.He said: “We talked a moment ago about whether someone is Remain or Leave, whether someone is black or white, North or South, urban or rural, and whatever happens this is the number one thing, we have to address in our countrywe are staying together as a cohesive society.“I think it is incumbent upon all politicians, especially when we see around the world, in the US, Italy and others, there are politicians that want to feed off anger and feed off ision, that we as Conservatives always look at the best in people and try to bring them together.”He said he had lived with prejudice for most of his le – but believed Britain was the “most successful multi-racial democracy in the world”.The new International Development Secretary launched his leadership bid in The Spectator and has since told of his one-time opium use.The Penrith MP has been scathing about a No Deal Brexit and claimed it would be a huge mistake, damaging, unnecessary, and I think also dishonest.Rory Stewart has outlined his intention to fulfil Brexit and use a citizens assembly and a grand jury to help parliament to hammer out a deal with the EU that works for the country.Stewart believes a No Deal Brexit would cause huge financial implications for Brexit and is focused on a practical deal.He said he would lock up MPs over the summer to get the deal done.Hes also said hell build two million new homes.Apparently undeterred by winning only  votes in the first round, Stewarts insists hes the only one who can stop Boris Johnson in the PM race.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: as long as boris doesnt mess up britain
story: I followed him outside to discover my crumpled coat lying in the passenger footwell, discarded sweet wrappers scattered like confetti, a takeaway coffee cup lying on the back seat and the glove box gaping like a shocked mouth. In other words . . . the car was exactly as I’d left it.“Well at least they didn’t steal anything,” I mumbled. The first he’ll know of the truth is when he reads this. Tidiness isn’t one of my strong points and nor, it seems, is PM hopeful Boris Johnson in possession of the neatness gene.The photo of his Toyota Previa’s interior makes my messy misdemeanours seem very Mini indeed. Naturally, with the age-old adage of “tidy room, tidy mind” at the forefront of their smugly neat brains, plenty will make the leap that Boris’s untidiness makes him unsuitable to lead the country.His many critics might also throw in the other car-related evidence that, when he was GQ’s motoring correspondent, he accrued enough parking tickets to paper a downstairs loo and frequently misplaced the vehicle he’d been loaned.A potential PM needs to be across the small print of every situation, they argue, and Boris is just too “chaotic” to do so. But is that true  After all, Gordon Brown and Theresa May were sticklers for detail and look what happened to them.So perhaps it’s time for a “bigger picture” personality with the strength of character to lead the country through a series of inevitably dficult decisions while leaving the crossing of Ts etc to several trusted lieutenants.According to journalist Andrew Gilligan, who worked for Boris when he was Mayor of London, his former boss has the “factory setting” of one nation Toryism and the ability to “master detail whenever he wanted to” but seldom wanted to.“A leader’s job,” Gilligan adds, “is to set the general direction and tone, choose the right people and inspire them to implement it. Lots of folk can do detail.”My friends would tell you that, despite the chaotic mess of my office at home , I possess clarity of thought when it comes to work and le’s general admin.So let’s hope that,he becomes PM, Boris is the same. Watch this messy space.MODEL Irina Shayk has reportedly split from Hollywood actor Bradley Cooper, father of her young daughter.The couple haven’t confirmed or denied the reports, but the rumour mill went in to turbo- boosted overdrive when Irina was spotted leaving their US home with this suitcase.Puh. The story might be true, but this puny bag proves nothing. It would just about hold her mascaras.ANY chance of seeing all of Prince Archie  So far we’ve been treated to a glimpse of his nose and one cheek when Meghan and Harry posed for the first post-birth photocall, followed by a pair of feet on Mother’s Day and, on Father’s Day last weekend, just his eyes.It’s like playing a royal version of Beetle Drive.LIAM GALLAGHER has given a “Father’s Day” interview along with three of his four children by four dferent women.He’s a lucky man that, despite his often erratic behaviour and, in his oldest daughter’s case, a -year absence, all the mothers have clearly brought up their children to bear no ill will towards him. Good for them.Not all dads are as lucky and, consequently, many spent yet another Father’s Day estranged from their children through no fault of their own.My thoughts are with them.VIETNAMESE model Ngoc Trinh is in trouble with officials in her home country after wearing this barely-there frock to a film screening at the Cannes Film Festival.Nguyen Ngoc Thien, Vietnam’s Minister of Culture, Sports and Tourism, says: “Her outfit was improper, offensive and has caused public outrage.”A matter of opinion, of course, but he’s launched an investigation that could lead to a heavy fine for Ms Trinh. Personally, I found myself more intrigued that she was attending the premiere of A Hidden Le, a thought-provoking film about a conscientious objector who refuses to fight for the Nazis in World War Two.Ms Trinh isn’t in it and, as far as I can tell, wasn’t reviewing it either. Meaning, presumably, that she was simply working the red carpet to boost not only the movie but her impressive .million Instagram followers who slavishly follow her every, choreographed move.No such thing as A Hidden Le in the modern world, eh In the morning and evening rush hour, you’re luckyyou reach ten.ENGLAND women’s football manager Phil Neville and his we Julie have completed a £million makeover of their home, including a cinema with armchairs that extend to become beds.Eek. We have footstools in our living room and I barely get halfway through a film without nodding off.If we had beds, I wouldn’t outlast the opening credits.A GROWING number of four-year-olds can’t hold a pencil when they start primary school.The Educational Institute of Scotland was told the crisis could be blamed on councils replacing pre-school teachers with lower-paid child develop-ment officers so many nurseries have “no educational input”.Do you seriously need to have trained as a teacher to show a child how to hold a pencil YET another US-based fitness instructor has come forward to claim that Sir Philip Green was a little too hands-on during their one-on-one gym sessions.Jenner McAmis, , says she called it “taking one for the team” when she saw Green – who denies any impropriety or wrongdoing – for two-hour sessions five times a week. know . . . shocking, right Ten hours a week of working out and he still looks like this. The ongoing investigation prevents me from making further comment on the accusations of groping.But in the meantime, let’s see how many of Mr Green’s A-lister friends are photographed with him on this summer’s sailing trip around the Med’s hotspots.THE Sun’s Give It Back campaign is aimed at pressurising the Government to plug the £million funding gap for care services for disabled kids.Spearheading it are parents Vickey and Adrian Kowal, whose seven-year-old son Ollie suffers from a one-in-a-million condition that means any muscle could become paralysed at any moment and kill him.That means round-the-clock care from his mum and dad who have never received any respite care from local health or social services teams. Promises have been made, but the funding or care needed has yet to materialise.So,you’d prefer your taxes to go to families like the Kowals, instead of throwing millions at foreign countries with corrupt regimes, please visit thesun olliesletter to sign your support.They need , signatures and are currently at just over ,, so every signature matters. Thank you.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: noel gallagher brexit liberal elite
story: Talented bloke, decent songwriter and usually spoke a bit of sense. He’s just done so again.People who want a second vote on Brexit should go and live in North Korea, he said. Meaning that they had no time for democracy.Gallagher — like almost every bloody pop musician — backed Remain in the ­referendum. But he said: “There’s only one f***ing thing worse than a fool who voted for Brexit. That’s the rise of the c***s trying to get the vote overturned.”His message, then, to the relentlessly moaning Remainers who have tried every trick in the book to get that democratic decision overturned is: Don’t look back in anger — get on with your lives and let Brexit happen.As we decided it must.And here’s the thing. I suspect most Remainers think exactly the same. The people I know who voted Remain were saddened by the referendum result and they wished we’d all voted dferently.But they all believe that the vote must be upheld. And there should not be a second vote.And when I talk to them, they don’t call me a Nazi or a fascist for voting Leave.They don’t suggest I’m too thick to be allowed to vote or that I hate all foreigners.They just agree to dfer on that simple issue of in or out, and there’s no bad ­feeling at all.This is the thing. The politicians and commentators insist Brexit has ­brutally ided the nation. That the wounds will take a long time to heal. That we’re all at each other’s throats. The .million versus the .million.It’s not so at all. title: facebook digital currency libra ross clark
story: Now Mark Zuckerberg’s leviathan wants to democratise banking by launching a digital currency for us all, but particularly those without a bank account.Libra will be launched next year in association with  other companies including Uber, Spoty, Mastercard, eBay and Vodafone.Facebook claims Libra will make it easier, cheaper and more secure to pay for things via the internet ­compared with bank cards or other forms of payment.Libra can be sent to other users “as easily and instantly as a text message”. It will be a shiny new global currency for the st Century, taking on the dollar and the Pound.But I’m not fooled. I think we all know what Facebook is really up to.This is yet another way to harvest data about our financial habits which it can then use for targeted marketing. Critics are already calling it the “most invasive and dangerous form of surveillance ever designed”.Collecting and exploiting information about us is, after all, the whole reason for the company’s existence.Years ago it was basic stuff, like quizzes asking, “What kind of personality type are you ”Fill that in and you are practically begging to be ­targeted in marketing and ­political campaigns. But handing over our spending details is quite another matter.This may be spun as ­connecting the world and ­revolutionising payments but it is really all about tapping the modern-day version of oil — the wells of data.Facebook already knows who you are. Accept Libra and it will know what you are buying, who you’re paying and how much you have.Will it be regulated by the UK Financial Conduct Authority, as banks are in this country  Certainly, the company has not shown much desire for regulation so far — of which more later.But what do we know about how trustworthy, secure or morally sound this would-be money broker is The Cambridge Analytica scandal, where data from million users was shared with political consultants, led to a fine of £, by ­Britain’s Information ­Commissioner’s Office.Last September the company admitted that data from million of its users had leaked due to a security flaw.In  it failed to stop the live broadcast of the torture of a disabled man in Chicago. It has also refused to take down neo-Nazi content.Facebook is under criminal investigation by US prosecutors who are looking into data-sharing deals with, among other, Amazon and Apple. It has been caught out farming data from apps whose users might have been unaware they were feeding information to Facebook.The company was found to be harvesting the dates of female users’ periods via an app which tracked ovulation.Facebook has also been accused of doing little to protect ­vulnerable children from ­promotions of self-harm. British father Ian Russell has directly linked Facebook-owned Instagram to the suicide of his -year-old daughter, Molly.Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg refused to attend the UK ­Parliament’s committee on ­disinformation and “fake news” last year, amid concern the social media giant is ­positioning itself as a news publisher but without ­compliance with any of the regulation or laws governing traditional journalism.The  has been blamed for spreading hatred. In March this year an ­Australian white supremacist live-streamed on Facebook his massacre of  people at two New Zealand mosques.It has further been accused of putting IS terrorists in touch with each other via its “suggested friends” application.When challenged as to why it does not do more to tackle ­terrorism, it falls back on the explanation that it does not have the technology to watch what its .billion users are doing all the time.Yet somehow that does not seem to stop it farming commercially valuable data from our accounts.The same will no doubt turn out to be true about Libra. This week French finance ­minister Bruno Le Maire warned that the cryptocurrency would inevitably be used by terrorists and criminals to sht money around undetected.When it happens, Facebook will no doubt shrug its corporate shoulders once more and say it is powerless to stop it.In theory, the very complex nature of cryptocurrencies means that it should be near impossible for anyone to steal our money.But we have all heard the horror stories. The best-known cryptocurrency, ­Bitcoin, ­at first soared in value, ­making millions for people who latched on to it early. But  months ago it crashed.Of course, most of us like to shop on the internet — and e-commerce is only likely to grow in the coming years.But most of us do it with our bank cards or direct from accounts which hold our money in a ­currency which is backed by the central bank of a First World country.This means we can be ­reasonably sure the currency won’t ­suddenly disappear or become valueless. It is quite another matter doing business in a currency that is backed by internet firms.How can we be sure that Facebook will still be around in a few years’ time Of course, banks sometimes go bust, but at least we have some protection in the form of the Government’s financial services compensation scheme which will refund up to £, of savings in the event of a failure.Facebook claims Libra will be backed by an independent foundation in Switzerland and will be free from the kind of speculation that drove the value of Bitcoin, because its value will be linked to a basket of currencies.But I’m sorry, I’m just not buying it. I’m sticking with sterling when I do my online shopping.It might not be very exciting but I feel confident it will still be around well when Libra, and Facebook, have long ago ­disappeared. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: parents school ditch traditional uniform tracksuit
story: Pupils will now wear blue and white tracksuit bottoms with a zip up track top emblazoned with the school crest.Almost  per cent of families - around  parents - objected to the plans at Telford Junior School in Leamington Spa, Warks.The previous unorm policy was black or grey trousers and skirts, a white polo-shirt and a blue fleeced cardigan with black shoes.Black shoes have been replaced with non-branded white or black trainers.Parent Teresa Huggins told the BBC: When you first hear the words tracksuits for unorms you think theyre going to be chavvy and tacky but they are far from that... my two sons love them.Another mum, who asked to remain anonymous, feared the unorm change could negatively impact on the childrens mindset.She said: I could understand the children going to school in games kits on days they had sports but to be wearing it every day I think will put the children in a dferent mindset towards school.A number of families have pointed out the increased expense, with the branded items starting at £. from the schools unorm shop.Mum Danielle Lenton said the greater cost was notable but liked the concept.She added: Personally I will purchase it for my year  pupil for his last year and hand this down to my year  pupil for when she needs it as its mostly unisex.Parents also raised concerns about the children sitting around in smelly clothes after games lessons.Facebook users slammed the proposal when it was first suggested in October.Wayneo Worrallo wrote: Setting them up for the track suit way of le for when they finish school....... One time Star!Ben Dolan wrote: Give them a free kne whilst theyre at it.Bryn Arnold wrote: When youve got lessons till .pm and ASBOs to attain at pm...Al Williams wrote: About twenty years ago my childrens school brought in polo shirts, sweatshirts etc. I now see they have reintroduced smart blazers and skirts  trousers. I think the children are more in work mode when wearing smart clothes.Kev Mitchell wrote: What is the world coming to  !! Awful idea and I dont even have kids.John Dargue wrote: Dress smart, think smart.Head teacher Richard Siviter wrote to parents in October about the change, which affects  pupils aged seven to .He said the unorm would be worn throughout the day, without the need to change into games kit for PE games lessons, adding that it simplies the school unorm and reduces costs to families.Mr Siviter also said it will save valuable lesson time and overcomes the issue of changing in school - reducing lost property.The community was asked for views on a new unorm for the  pupils, aged from seven to .Plans for a hoodie were dropped after consultation but governors greenlighted sportswear with two-thirds of students in favour.Mr Siviter told the BBC the unorm would serve a more active curriculum and has received a very positive response from pupils.But Mr Siviter said PE would take place in the afternoon.Mr Siviter added: We feel on balance that it was worth doing and theres been a very positive response from the children.

title: snog fm messages investigation
story: The message flashes onto my screen, just moments after I told him I was .His name is Andre, and we “met” through snog.fm – a website based on a hit BBC Three TV show that allows people to rate each other as “snog, marry, avoid”.And within minutes of me creating a profile with a photo of my -year-old self, I had already received “snogs” from accounts with names like “grabatit” while anonymous stranger “justheretowatch” rates me as a “marry”.The website was recently thrown into the spotlight when it was used by web designer Gareth Hughes, then , to seduce a teen.He was jailed for six years and eight months after admitting a string of offences, including having a secret sexual relationship for four years between  and .But despite insisting “security and safe guarding” their users is a main priority, and changing the website to become + only, it’s only too easy for a vulnerable teen to sign up.And while parents may not have heard of the website before, the site can attract more than .m page views a day.Although it is unclear just how many accounts are registered, there are more than million interactions between users recorded - Trouble is always fun when you don’t get caught.”We keep chatting about history homework and sport when he adds: “Sad I can’t date you.”Charities have revealed how online grooming is one of the biggest threats to young people with more than , online offences recorded by police in the last  months.Girls aged  to  are the most likely to be targeted by groomers, with attempts more than tripling through social media sites like Instagram.And scrolling through snog.fms livefeed, you can watch as accounts snog, marry and avoid others, judging simply on their pictures.More than .million answers have already been given as men and women rate each other on the shallow site.Some say they are  years old, while one lists himself as  and under the name gimmethatbooty.After it launched eight years ago, it branded itself as “a way for young people to break the ice and interact without the awkwardness of traditional dating sites”.But its easy ability to sign up and chat has sparked warnings from young women, who say they were immediately bombarded with seedy messages.One woman, Chloe Mills, said she signed up to the website when she was just .The -year-old Nando’s worker, told The Sun Online said she would use the site for “hours at a time” thanks to it giving her a quick confidence boost.But she said: “I felt pressure to upload provocative photos, but that was never me. That would happen a lot.“I did feel pressured to show off cleavage in the pictures, a lot of the girls were. My friends used to get creepy messages too. title: nan given asbo wearing bikini in garden
story: Ex-model Kay Crane was given an order preventing her from wearing the swimming costume in her garden, claiming it was in view of children from a nearby nursery.The nuisance notice issued last November was one of , handed out by cash-strapped councils across the UK over the last five years.Kay was banned from wearing a bikini inside her home -near windows.She and partner Dennis Woolf, , were also told they couldnt play loud music, or watch or shout at the children at the adjoining nursery to her house in Stockport in Greater Manchester.But the gran today posed in her bright bikini, saying: I don’t understand why I can’t wear a bikini in my own garden.She added: It’s not like I wear it all the time - just when the weather is really hot.I think the council are just trying to bully us. They’re just trying to ride roughshod over us because they don’t care about older people.But it won’t stop me wearing my bikini.Kay, who used to model for fashion houses, says the dispute with the council began last May when she was given a Community Protection Notice , a new-style of Asbo .That was later withdrawn but the council took her to court and she had to give a general undertaking not to engage in behaviour which caused “harassment, alarm or distress”.But she denied shouting at the children and claims she only listened to talkSPORT on her radio in the back garden.She said: I don’t think any of the children were upset by my bikini. Young children don’t care what you wear.Whatwas on a beach  Would children get upset there too In April the council wrote to her sayingshe continued to breach the undertaking, which is in force until  December, they would begin committal proceedings in court.Committal proceedings involve charges of contempt of court and anyone found to be in contempt can be sent to prison for two months.Kay insists the dispute stems from the nursery’s decision to expand and build a car-park at the back of her home.She claims the nursery decided to turn the car park into an adventure playground but the owners are still waiting for retrospective planning approval.She added: They cut down lots of trees and plants and made a real mess when they did the building work.I can’t understand they are getting upset about me in my bikini after everything we put up with.What century are we living in for goodness sake A spokesman for the council said the case had caused a great deal of alarm and distress to the kids at the nursery.They said: We have tried to work with Ms Crane as much as possible, and whilst wearing a bikini is not a breach of the undertaking agreed in court, staring at the children, shouting at the children and watching the children playing whilst wearing a bikini in full view are some of the repeated behaviours that have caused concern and are classed as a breach of the undertaking.The number of notices - dubbed a “busybodies charter” - have increased by  per cent from , in   to , in  , according to Freedom of Informationrequests.They can be handed out for anti-social behaviour by council or police officers.Violating the order is punishable by on-the-spot fines of £ ortaken to court a fine of up to £,. Councils retain the fine revenue.Ten councils issued Community Protection Notices against people feeding birds, and one took action against a resident who put up cat deterrents to stop the pets fouling their house or harassing birdle.Another woman, Estelle, who had kept free range chickens for seven years on her rural smallholding in Gloucestershire without complaint, got a CPN warning ordering her to keep them in a pen, following a complaint from a neighbour.Josie Appleton, director of the Manesto Club who sent the FOIs, said: At least Asbos had to go through court and you had a right to a defence. These new orders are a scandal in comparison - you can be issued with a legal order by a town centre warden filling in a form.“These powers need to be urgently reviewed, and drastic changes made, to avoid further injustice and innocent people being penalised.”A Home Office spokesperson said: “Anti-social behaviour harms communities and can severely impact people’s way of le, which is why we have reformed the tools and powers available to tackle it.“There is a clear legal test for issuing a Community Protection Notice, and our statutory guidance highlights that agencies should have sufficient evidence to satisfy themselves that the behaviour in question is genuinely having a detrimental effect on others’ quality of le, rather than being a behaviour that others may just find annoying.”

title: mh370 flight pilot agitated frayed nerves
story: Captain Zaharie Ahmad Shah was widely reported by close friends and family as being distracted, agitated and withdrawn in the weeks before the aircraft’s disappearance.Mystery surrounds what happened to the Boeing  from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing, which disappeared with  people on board from radars over the South China Sea shortly after take-off in March .In July last year, investigators released a -page report, saying the planes controls were likely deliberately manipulated to take it off course.The responsibly for the planes route off course has largely been placed in the hands of its troubled married -year-old pilot.Shahs background and turbulent state of mind before the flight has been the focus for much of the evidence.His we, Faizah Khanum, revealed he spent solitary hours on his flight simulator and stopped talking to her before the death-e crash.Over the course of several interviews, she told police how her husband became increasingly distracted in the months leading up to the flight.I found him distant and dficult to understand’ she said.She told investigators that although they continued to live in the same house, Zaharie spent his time alone.Faizah said her husband was so withdrawn he hardly spoke to his sons and was not close to them.She revealed how he always spent time alone in his room with the simulator he had built himself.Its since been claimed he rehearsed the plane’s fatal flight on the home-made device.Faizah said: He just retreated into a shell.The mother-of-three said she became worried as her husband increasingly became distracted and withdrawn as their marriage crumbled.Shah had reportedly refused pleas to attend marriage counselling sessions to improve the relationship, and is said to have had extramarital affairs.His daughter Aishah was also interviewed in detail by police in Kuala Lumpur.The -year-old said during her final conversation with her dad she barely recognised him.She said: He wasn’t the father I knew. He seemed disturbed and lost in a world of his own.Alarming testimonies from friends also pointed towards his fragile and concerning behaviour.One friend described how the pilot would pace the empty rooms of his home in Malaysia like a caged tiger.Shah criticised the Malaysian government more than  times on social media, including branding then-Prime Minister Najib Razak a “moron” on Facebook.He was a fervent supporter of Anwar Ibrahim, a pro-democracy icon in Malaysia who was jailed for five years for sodomy hours before Flight MH took off for the final time.His daughter Aishah also told investigators she knew from friends in Kuala Lumpur he was upset and felt ‘utter frustration’ over the jail sentence given to Anwar Ibrahim.Anwar’s supporters believe it was a politically motivated prosecution.A group of aviation experts assembled for the Australian TV programme  Minutes, broadcast in May .They claimed they may have solved the aviation mystery.They all agreed that Shah deliberately ditched the plane in the Indian Ocean west of Australia.Former Australia Transport Safety Bureau head Martin Dolan added: This was planned, this was deliberate, and it was done over an extended period of time.Malaysia Airlines Flight MH took off from Kuala Lumpur and was heading to Beijing with  people on board.Passengers included Chinese calligraphers, a couple on their way home to their young sons after a long-delayed honeymoon and a construction worker who hadnt been home in a year.But at .am on March , , Malaysia Airlines lost contact with MH close to Phuket island in the Strait of Malacca.Before that, Malaysian authorities believe the last words heard from the plane, from either the pilot or co-pilot, was Good night Malaysian three seven zero.Satellite pings from the aircraft suggest it continued flying for around seven hours when the fuel would have run out.Experts have calculated the most likely crash site around , miles west of Perth, Australia.But a huge search of the seabed failed to find any wreckage - and there are a number of alternative theories as to its fate.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: giant cow guinness world record longest horns
story: Poncho the seven-year-old Texas longhorn steer smashed the previous record holder by more than an inch.He lives on a ranch in Goodwater, Alabama, just outside the Birmingham metro area.The Pope family have owned Poncho since he was just six months old.In a video interview with Guinness World Records, Jeral Pope Jr. said: Ponchos horns curl and twist and go straight out.Its so neat to see the dferences and iation of the horn mass and how they grow. The ones that go straight out like Ponchos make it so much more impressive on total tip-to-tip .The Popes first noticed their cows record-breaking potential when he reached the age of four.His horns were growing outwards, instead of curving upwards, meaning they achieve a much greater width.Poncho is said to be a gentle giant, with a taste for apples, carrots and marshmallows.Mr Pope said: This ones had so many people over the years stop by to see him, feeding him carrots and apples and any kind of treats that hes just turned into a wonderful big pet.

title: man pub tap water medication barmaid swipes phone
story: Johnathan White, , filmed the woman telling him youve gotta go home at the Clock Hotel pub in North Tyneside.He was out with his pal Shaun and claims the barmaid told him to pay £ for the water or leave the pub.In the video Johnathan repeatedly asksshe is refusing him water even though Ive got a medical condition - which is depression - at the about .pm on June .She can be heard saying: If youve got a medical condition, youve gotta go home.Johnathan insists he needs the water to take his antidepressants.The woman then says you can tape us as much as you like before appearing to swipe at his phone.He says the confrontation has left him shocked and upset, and already vulnerable.Johnathan reported it to Northumbria police who are asking anyone with information to come forward.He said: I was anxious and scared. She wasnt supposed to be charging us anyway for tap water. When I raised this with her, she made me feel really vulnerable.I was made to feel stupid and insecure around her. Shaun thought she was nasty. I even told her that Id bought two pints, and then she hit me.I couldnt see why she wouldnt just pour me a glass of water for my medication.He added he was surprised he was being charged £ for tap water and claimed he only brought two pints worth of cash with him.Johnathan also doesnt have a contactless debit card and his American Express card wasnt working.A spokesperson for Northumbria Police said: Shortly before pm, June , police received a report of an assault at the Clock Hotel, Hebburn.Enquiries are ongoing and anyone with any information is asked to contact police by calling  and quoting reference number    .The Clock Hotel has been contacted for comment.

title: jim ratcliffe neighbours internet
story: Sir Jim Ratclfe,  — who is worth £billion — ordered builders to dig up a road to lay fibre optics.The tycoon offered to share the internet speed with neighbours including Dire Straits star Mark Knopfler — but onlythey paid for it. Letters were delivered to ten houses at the site requesting contributions, although no amount was mentioned.The works are thought to have cost tens of thousands of pounds.One neighbour said: “Hes a bloody billionaire. If he wants it, why doesn’t he just pay for it ”The ,ft trench is also to carry electricity to a mansion that Sir Jim — founder of chemical giant INEOS — is having built at public Thorns Beach, near Beaulieu, Hants.But locals say it has hampered access, claiming it is big that walkers can get past onlyconstruction workers switched off their machinery.Sir Jim, who lives in Monaco, flattened a bungalow at the site to make way for the futuristic mansion. It is thought he will use it for holidays.But he has further upset neighbours by installing security to guard the site.The neighbour said: “We’ve had bloody security while they were digging. Mr Ratclfe doesn’t even live here.”He added: “The trench was dug to put electricity through to the new house. It was supposed to be that he wanted superfast broadband put in, but onlywe all paid a contribution.”A spokesman for Sir Jim said: “There’s nothing to say, really.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mechanic forgot bolt on cars front wheels

title: old english sheepdog owners dulux dog
story: Only  puppies were registered in the first three months of , down  per cent from last year – putting the famous breed on the “at watch” list.  Six owners tell Kate Jackson and Lynsey Hope their shaggy-dog love stories – and reckon the rest of us are just barking mad not to have one as a pet.WAREHOUSE worker Martin Law, above, and his partner, cleaner Ellen Simmons, both , from Walsall, adopted Kane, eight, from a Blue Cross rehoming centre in Suffolk two months ago. Martin says:“Kane was kept in a small yard and never walked. I had only ever owned Labradors, but when we came to looking for a new dog, we saw Kane and fell in love.He has such a lovely nature, so friendly and completely stupid at times. Despite what he’s been through, he didn’t have any trouble settling in with us and our three grown-up daughters.“We have had to build him up slowly to get him walking again. Every time he sees his lead it’s like Christmas for him.“He weighs around st lb, but he still thinks he can curl up on your lap. He also loves a cuddle in bed at night. He sprawls out for a fuss for  minutes then goes to his own bed.”HELEN POINTON , , a personal assistant, lives in Rugby, Warks, with husband Ian, , a farmer, and Boots, , Peru, four, and -month-old Bandit. Helen says:“I’ve had Old English sheepdogs for  years. I was a big David Bowie fan and I’d wanted one ever since I saw one featured in the movie Labyrinth.“Once you’ve had an Old English, you’ll either never have any other breed – or you’ll never have another dog. What can put people off is caring for the coat. It can take hours to brush them.“We imported Bandit from Holland because of his breed lines and plan to breed with Bandit and Peru.He’s also had a very successful start to his show career. Puppies tend to sell for £ to £, which is not unreasonable, as the health checks can cost hundreds of pounds.“Away from shows, they are wonderful pets and Bandit is always a big hit with children.”ELIZABETH AMOS, , a retired interior designer, and husband Cyril, , live in Gloucester with mum and daughter Lottie, four, and Emily, ten months. Gran-of-four Elizabeth says:“I grew up with an Old English sheepdog called Flicker. We used to hide under the table and I was devastated when she died when I was six.“I bought my own – Bessie – when I was . She was a typical Old English, boisterous, friendly and fantastic with children.“When I brought my first child, James, home from hospital Bessie had a snf of his head and that was it, they became great friends.“They would spend hours in the garden playing football. Since Bessie I’ve owned five Old English sheepdogs – Daisy, May, Molly and our current ones Lottie and Emily.“It’s lovely having two of these big dogs in the house. Whenever I sit on the sofa with Cyril, they insist on joining us, too – it looks like we’re covered in huge white fluffy cushions.“The vet bills can be expensive and the biggest health concern I’ve experienced is sensitive stomachs.“The other expense is grooming. But I groom my two dogs myself. I’ve taught myself through trial and error.“Yes, they can be high maintenance, but they’re great family dogs and fit in with your lestyle. They’re worth the effort and cost.”JEANETTE HOWSAM, , from Spalding, Lincs, has five Old English sheepdogs – Molly, , Lizzy, nine, Pickles, six, Georgie, three, and Denzil,  weeks. Jeanette, above, is married to David, , a railway worker, and the couple have three grown-up children and eight grandkids. She says:“I’m mad about these dogs. They’re incredibly loyal and follow me around the house like a shadow.“All of them have their own little quirks. Yes, they’re big animals and lively as puppies, but they do chill out when they get older.“Six years ago I started breeding them. I’m a hobby breeder, so I don’t breed a litter every year. And I don’t do it for money, it’s for the love of the dogs.“Lizzy and Pickles have had  pups between them, and I’m incredibly careful about who I breed them with. The breed has a number of health problems like hip dysplasia, PCD – a respiratory lung condition – and eye and ear problems. This is why it’s so important to buy from a reputable breeder who can show you the health certicates for both parents.“Finding a reputable breeder is hard. Only seven Assured Breeders are currently listed with the Kennel Club. Old English sheepdogs are high maintenance. I show mine and getting Georgie ready for the ring takes four hours from her being bathed to being brushed and dry.“Then there’s clipping the hair between their paws and cleaning their eyes and ears. A professional groom costs around £, but I do it myself.“Sometimes looking after the dogs does feel like a full-time job. But I don’t regret devoting so much of my time to them. You can’t beat the personality of these dogs, they’re always happy and great fun.”ELLEN WHEELER, , from Lincolnshire, owns Madison, the current Dulux dog. Ellen says:“When I take Madison for a walk I get stopped constantly as people always want to make a fuss of her.“People point at her as they drive past in their cars and you always see people going ‘Ahhhh’ when they see her. Madison puts a smile on everyone’s face and wherever we go she is the centre of attention.“She’s been the official face of Dulux for three years, after I was approached by someone from the firm at a dog show.“I’ve met people who have travelled three hours just to meet her. She’s had two puppy litters and four of her pups will appear with her in the latest Dulux ad. I can’t wait to see it on TV, they are all so adorable.“Sheepdogs make great pets, they love to be around people. But I wouldn’t recommend them for everyone. They like to have company and their coat takes a lot of grooming.“You have to know what you are getting into.”RECEPTIONIST Evie Bell and her husband Steve, a gas fitter, both , live in Salisbury, Wilts, with three-year-old Milo. Evie says:“I’ve had a lot of dogs in my le but none of them has the personality of an Old English.“Milo is a complete clown. He makes us laugh every day. He’s a massive attention seeker and loves a fuss.“Everyone wants to pet him, especially when he has his long winter coat.“I spend about  minutes a night grooming him, far more time than I put into my own hair.“If he was a show dog, we’d need to brush him for an hour or two every night.“I’m only ft in, so when he stands on his hind legs he’s taller than me, and he weighs more than six stone.“He’s a big, friendly giant though – so sociable and funny. It makes me sad to hear they are so unpopular.“Everyone just seems to want a cockapoo at the moment because that’s the fashionable dog, but I’d recommend an Old English in a heartbeat.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: can boris do prime minister
story: From the start, this has been the contest the Boris campaign has wanted. They feel Hunt is the ideal opponent.He voted Remain in , he has been in Cabinet throughout Theresa May’s premiership with its Brexit failures and he is a mild-mannered figure who struggles to impose himself on debates.One Boris backer jokes that they have never seen, “a more lop-sided two-horse race”.The Hunt campaign bristle at the idea that this is going to be a walkover.They believe he has a route to victory by playing on Tory members’ concerns about whether Boris can actually do the job of being PM.They also think they will do well with the large Scottish membership — Scots are twice as likely to be members of the Tory party than the English — and are planning an early campaign trip there.They expect to pick up the endorsement of Ruth Davidson, the popular leader of the Scottish Conservatives.But for all Jeremy Hunt’s efforts to make this a contest, it is still Boris Johnson’s to lose. Of course, he could. He could make a spectacular gaffe or some scandal could blow up.Last night’s revelations of the screaming match at the flat he shares with his new partner shows the scrutiny that his le is going to come under.If he can get through the next fortnight without any major blunders, he’ll become Tory leader.Why  Because the postal votes go out from July  and most Tory members willthem within two days.As one Tory veteran explains: “A week after the ballots have gone out, it is too late to change anything.”I understand Boris will use the next weeks to set out his Brexit position in more detail.Those hoping to see him in full entertainer mode at these hustings will be disappointed. Instead, he intends to stick to the serious persona of the past few weeks.One of those preparing him for the month tells me that Tory members “know he can do Boris. They need to see him do Prime Minister.”This new, more serious approach won’t stop the attacks.Boris’s critics have lost their judgement and want to attack him as a homophobe, despite the fact he was one of the first politicians to back gay marriage. Just as absurdly, they want to smear him as a racist.Oddly, these attacks actually create a problem for Jeremy Hunt.The more ridiculous the criticism Boris faces, the more Tory activists will rally to him. This will make it harder for Hunt to get a hearing for his far more measured criticisms of Boris.All of these hustings will be broadcast on the internet. I understand the Boris campaign were not best pleased about this, which suggests they still have some concerns about their candidate slipping up.But even in this age of political upsets, it is hard to believe that Boris Johnson won’t be the winner of this contest.EDDIE Lister is to run the transition team that will prepare Boris Johnson’s governing programme.Lister, chief of staff for Boris when he was Mayor of London, will take charge of this process and the working assumption is that having done this, he will move to No as chief of staffBoris becomes PM.Crucially, Boris knows and trusts Lister. In his successful stint at City Hall, Lister showed that he knew how to bring order to Boris world – which is no mean feat.One of those close to the decision tells me: “Boris has made the biggest shout, who is your number one man  It is Eddie.” The need for order is urgent.If Boris enters Downing Street, he’ll only have  days until October , the day by which he has promised Britain will be out of the EU. He won’t have any time to lose.Intriguingly, I understand that Sajid Javid – who was knocked out of the leadership race on Thursday – was interested in doing this role.But the Johnson camp wanted whoever ran the transition to become the Downing Street chief of staff. A key challenge for Lister will be to make sure there is a clear structure.Boris has always liked having multiple sources of advice.As one of those who has known him for years observes: “There are going to be lots of dferent courts, lots of people competing for the monarch’s ear – and he quite likes that.”But this source warns that, “as a recipe for government, it could be quite fractious”.It is Lister’s job to make sure there is a clear chain of command.I understand that the spoilt ballot papers weren’t covered in graffiti, but simply left blank.“THE problem is the ,” says one of those preparing Boris for government.The  is a reference to those Tory MPs who voted for Rory Stewart before his elimination from the leadership contest.If only a fraction of this group decides to try to bind Boris Johnson’s hands on Brexit, then the Government could collapse.One of Boris’s closest allies warns that, “It is going to be really problematic, there is going to be a Remainer counterweight to the ERG”, the group of hardline Brexiteer MPs.To the alarm of Boris’ allies, Rory Stewart is uninterested in serving in a Boris Cabinet. Instead, he is setting himself up as an alternative voice on the backbenches.Stewart and his supporters have to remember, though, that a Corbyn government would be worse for this country than any Brexit outcome.The problem for Boris Johnson is that his Brexit strategy relies on MPs giving him time to seehe can use the threat of No Deal to winkle a concession out of the EU.The only chance of these  MPs giving him this time isthey think it is a bluff.“They have to believe it is a bluff, the ERG have to believe it is for real,” con- cedes one Boris ally.Pulling this off is going to be a political high-wire act.BORIS Johnson and Michael Gove have spoken since Gove’s elimination.I’m told the conversation wasn’t substantive but wasn’t rancorous, despite the tactical voting by Johnson supporters that led to Gove being knocked out.In the next few weeks Gove will get on with departmental business. He’ll introduce “Natasha’s law” for clearer labelling of allergens in products, named after Natasha Ednan-Laperouse, who died after eating a Pret sandwich, and increased sentences for those who abuse animals.I am told that it is “not settled one way or the other” whether Prime Minister Boris would keep Gove at the Environment department or offer him a bigger job. But given the scale of the challenges facing theTories, it would be foolish to not put their most talented departmental minister in one of the great offices of state.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bella thorne advice wise women whoopi goldberg
story: Whoopi pointed out, quite reasonably in my view, that the young actress should not have those sorts of images on her phone in the first place. She said everyone knows such photos can be hi- jacked and used to threaten and embarrass.I am sure that Whoopi meant well but it all backfired when an emotional Bella posted a video saying how upset she was at being “shamed” by the presenter and actress, — calling her actions “sick and disgusting”.I find it utterly baffling that Bella was more distressed by the words of a middle-aged woman who had her best interests at heart than the saddo who tried to embarrass her by releasing nude photos on to the internet for all the world to see.It’s a great shame this has now escalated into a row between the two women, because I truly admire Bella for how she has handled the whole potential blackmailing situation.It was a masterstroke and instantly took all the power away from the snivelling little git who was hassling her. Bella was not ashamed or embarrassed by the intimate pictures and would not be held to ransom. Good for her.But surely it was far more upsetting to be the victim of a potential crime than receiving a slight scolding from Whoopi for being naive enough to take and keep those sorts of images in the first place.Bella had a right old rant on Instagram and has vowed never again to appear on The View — a chat show co-hosted by Whoopi which is the US version of our Loose Women.I feel very sorry for Bella because she was clearly extremely upset by what Whoopi had to say but I think her anger is misplaced.Whoopi was makIng a really important point, which affects everyone, not only those in the public eye.She was speaking for worried parents of teenagers and twentysomethings everywhere who are concerned that online photos of their children getting drunk, posing nude or even having sex will come back to haunt them.It is one of the real dangers of social media that our accounts are not really secure. they can be hacked with relative ease, falling out of “the cloud” and on to your boss’s Facebook — or, even worse, getting viewed by your mum and dad.There are people who think it is a jolly wheeze to post explicit photographs of former lovers online, or who do it as “revenge” for being dumped.Of course, there are those who have no common sense and post pictures of themselves romping in hotel rooms with girlfriends or boyfriends or boozily feeling each other up on holiday.The authorities are now cracking down. Last August, a man who hacked into hundreds of iCloud accounts of Hollywood actresses and leaked their nude pictures was sentenced to eight months in prison.George Garofano stole private photographs from movie stars including actresses Jenner Lawrence and Kirsten Dunst. It was horribly distressing for these women and I completely sympathise.However, the ease with which that slimy toad was able to access personal images proves thatyou don’t want to have potentially embarrassing photos put out there, then don’t take them in the first place — or just press the delete button.Maybe even go back to the Dark Ages, invest in a Polaroid camera and keep your naughty pictures under lock and key. The hackers are vile, but let us not give them the ammunition. And take heed of the advice from wise women such as Whoopi.I SINCERELY hope the latest rumours from the troubled set of the new Bond film prove to be without foundation.It’s being claimed that the film’s director, Cary Fukunaga, held up cast and crew during a complicated shoot because he was playing video games on his PlayStation.Apparently the production crew and actors were not amused at having to hang about for three hours because Cary wanted to play with his toys. I don’t blame them.I cannot believe someone would be so inconsiderate to fellow professionals.I was, however, more aghast at finding out Cary isn’t a spotty teenage geek, but a -year-old man.Surely he should have outgrown PlayStation by now – especially when he is already in charge of the world’s best video game, involving Aston Martin car chases, shootouts, beautul women and dastardly villains.WILLIAM and Kate showed how royals should react when their lestyle causes harm to a member of the public.Widow Irene Mayor, , was hit by a police motorbike escorting the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge to Windsor Castle. She is in hospital with serious injuries.As soon as Wills and Kate found out, they sent flowers and a hand-written note and have told Irene’s family they want to visit her whenever she is ready.I HAVE never watched Love Island. So it’s odd to see images and videos of strange, orange people with impossibly white teeth, like Molly-Mae Hague on my online news feeds and splashed across magazines when I haven’t a blinking clue who they are.And it is utterly bizarre that they all look and sound exactly alike.To be honest,I really need to see fit youngsters strutting around, uttering meaningless sounds and having sex, I will tune into a David Attenborough documentary.THE Fab Five presenters on makeover show Queer Eye are making the world a better place – one scruffy, messed-up person at a time.Makeovers are hardly a new concept but this series does much more than give someone a new outfit and haircut.The hosts lovebomb shy misfits who ask for help, as well as big-hearted people who just neglect themselves – then change their lives for ever.It’s a show full of heart and soul and I blub during every episode.This week I met the British star of Queer Eye, delightful Tan France, from Doncaster. He had a hard time growing up in a world where he had no role models and he feels a huge responsibility to young gay Asian men such as himself.Tan and the Queer Eye boys feature in the video for Taylor Swt’s new single, You Need To Calm Down, with some of my favourite people including RuPaul and Ryan Reynolds.The song hits you over the head a bit with its inclusivity – no bad thing – but the Queer Eye boys do it better just by being themselves.I HAD to look twice at this gorgeous selfie posted by This Morning’s Alison Hammond.She’s glowing with confidence and happiness.After becoming the spokeswoman for a slimming club Alison has lost so much weight and looks stunning.She has talked about being “embarrassed” by weighing st. But I’m so glad she lost weight gradually with a healthy eating plan and doing exercise she loves.I wish Alison all the best with her battle towards being happier, healthier and fitter and I know she will have helped other women with their weight issues too.I BLOODY love Matt Lucas. The Little Britain star saw on Twitter that Amy Dunn was being bullied because she had lost her hair and was being derided as a “Matt Lucas lookalike”.The comedian immediately sent the -year-old a message of support telling her she was beautul and how flattered he was to be compared to her.Amy, who suffers from alopecia, has had people laughing and pointing at her in the street because she happens to have a condition that means she is bald.I hope having Matt on her side has cheered Amy up and given her the confidence to ignore the morons who hurled abuse, and maybe even feel sorry for them for being such ar**holes.Matt is right. Amy is beautul, and so is he.I’M very much liking the look of Beecham House, the new ITV drama set in th Century India that airs tomorrow night.The trails look sumptuous and now Poldark’s Aidan Turner has gone all grungy, leading man Tom Bateman is a most welcome piece of eye candy.Beecham House is on ITV tomorrow at pm.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: cabinet must stop theresa mays legacy plan
story: Some of her closest allies will not survive her departure. That is no reason now to help her force through a reckless spending spree which will hobble her successor post-Brexit.The Treasury has built up that “war chest” to handle the uncertainties of our future as a newly independent nation.It is not there to be plundered to make up for Mrs May’s failures since .Chancellor Philip Hammond is fighting to stop it.All his colleagues, but especially those with good prospects under a new leader, must back him.The Tories have a glimmer of a brighter future after three dismal years.It will be a disgraceoutgoing ministers sabotage it trying to rewrite the past.TORY minister Mark Field has rightly been suspended and apologised over his manhandling of a female eco protester.His force was excessive, even allowing for how little time he had to think as she strode towards the Chancellor’s table.But he cannot face criticism alone.The security was woeful. How could so many protesters stroll in, scream slogans and refuse to leave  No one was armed, but how could anyone be sure of that And why are authorities letting climate protesters believe they have a ine right to trespass  Or block major roads  Or wreck family holidays They now think that their hysterical claim to be “saving our planet from burning” trumps anyone ’s rights — a conviction fuelled by police feebly ­letting them paralyse London in April.Yet we are the first country to commit to net-zero emissions by . This year, the first time since the Industrial Revolution, more UK power will be produced from zero-carbon sources than fossil fuels.It’s time the sanctimonious outrage was directed somewhere it’s actually justied.THE latest drama surrounding Boris Johnson is troubling but madness has set in on the Left in its ­desperation to trash him.Every utterance over  years is being forensically examined for offences against “social justice” snowflakery.One half-witted Corbynite caricature, Laura ­Pidcock — an MP so keen to heal ision that she boasts of “viscerally” detesting all Tories — reckons Boris is “fuelled by homophobia and racism”.Which will be news to cosmopolitan, liberal-left London which twice elected him Mayor.But consider the stomach-churning hypocrisy of Labour’s hard left accusing a social liberal like Boris of being motivated by bigotry . . .When their own repugnant and blatant loathing of Jews has an entire community living in fear of a Corbyn Government.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: selfish mum jury duty replaced oap
story: Carly Hull, , was told by Judge Barbara Mensah that jury service was the only public service the state asks people to do in peacetime.The judge, who sits at Luton Crown Court, told Hull: On the th anniversary of the D-Day landings when people gave up their lives to ensure the freedoms we have in this country of a fair trial and of innocent until proven guilty, you think you can impose a selfish attitude to jury service.Hull, of Cook Road in Stevenage, was summoned before the judge having failed to attend for jury service earlier this month.She had first been called in February, but had jury service deferred until  June after she said she had childcare problems.Hull, a customer services worker at BQ, told Luton Crown Courts jury office that she had forgotten the date and had not received a letter telling her to attend.The jury officer again deferred her service until  June, but the judge said she then said that was not enough time to get childcare.The judge said: She said she would not have to do jury service as she had children and was not  years of age.Jury service is a vital part of the criminal law system of the UK and anyone over the age of  can be summoned to be a juror.Summons are based on the electoral role and in most circumstances you can face a fine of £,you dont attend.You can defer your jury serviceyou cant attend on the dates for which youve been summoned, but you have to give other dates in the next  months when you can attend instead.Judge Mensah told Hull, who stood in the witness box, shed had four months to make childcare arrangements.She said she would have received £.p a day on jury service to cover the costs with the local council providing a centre in Luton at half that rate.According to court staff, Hull said: Let a -year-old do it. I have got other things to do. I have a family to bring up.Defending, Stuart Sprawson said she lived in a rough area and the post informing her of the June date may not have been delivered.He said: I have emphasised jury service is fundamental public duty. Only on good reason are you excused.Her husband works for Affinity Water - he has contacted his employer.He is taking unpaid leave for five days next week to look after the children.She has also arranged for her mother, who works at the Lister Hospital, to look after the childrenthe jury service is extended.She accepts her defiance to court is not edying.She makes a sincere apology and did not appreciate the situation.Hull, who cried after the judges remarks, is due to start her jury service on Monday.Fining her, the judge said: I was not impressed with your attitude.If you are not here on Monday, the court will take more stringent action — you could go to prison.

But since then he has been off the radio and a podcast featuring himself with Gary Lineker called Behind Closed Doors has not released a new episode since the incident. Announcing his , Baker referred to a game played on his Five Live show about the sauce used on sausage sandwiches and said: “My own stand alone podcast, featuring all the old firm and even the Sausage Sandwich Game, will begin in the new year. “Emails encouraged, calls taken, subjects bizarre. “A twice a week meeting, we can rule the world.”  The tweet ended with the hashtag “#CandyManReturns” which is a reference to his radio nickname. Baker’s Saturday morning show ran on  Live from  until his dismissal last month. It had previously gained critical acclaim, winning the Gold Sony RadioAward in the Speech Radio Personality of the Year award for the ,  and , and the Gold Award for the Entertainment Show of the Year in . When he was sacked a BBC spokesperson said: “This was a serious error of judgment and goes against the values we as a station aim to embody. “Danny’s a brilliant broadcaster but will no longer be presenting a weekly show with us.” In , he was sacked from the same station after it was alleged he had incited threatening behaviour after a referee awarded a controversial penalty in an FA cup tie.   In , after his afternoon show on BBC London was axed, he said on Twitter : “BBC asked me not to say anything just yet about axing best show on British radio.“Why  Because it’s embarrassing  Because they’ll look bad ” He later branded his bosses “pinheaded weasels” during an on-air rant during the programme. A police investigation into Baker over his tweet was dropped several days after an allegation was made to Scotland Yard. A statement said: “An allegation was received by the politan Police Service on Thursday May  in relation to a tweet published on May . “Having reviewed the comments made, we do not consider that a criminal threshold has been met and as such we will be taking no further action.”

title: paul routledge dont switch off
story: NewsopinionPaul Routledge: Dont switch us off! Over-s revolt in Leeds over TV licencesMirrorman visits the front line of the protest against the decision to axe the benefitShareCommentsByPaul Routledge:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsopinionThe Mirrors Paul Routledge, centre, joined protestors in Leeds angry about the axed TV licence benefit "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThey came from all over Yorkshire to show their anger at the Tory-inspired raid on free TV licences for the over-s. Protesting pensioners, mostly ladies, filled the pavement outside the BBC’s northern HQ in Leeds. My, did they make a noise. And they were just one of  such demonstrations all over the country. Through the plate-glass windows of their plush offices, Beeb bosses must have got the message that the oldies are on the march. It must also be filtering through to the traitor Tory politicians who reneged on their manesto pledge to keep all pensioner benefits. Protesters waved placards showing a TV set with the message Don’t Switch Us Off! and they cheered as passing drivers hooted their support. Jacqueline Robinson, , from Castleford, is one cross lady.    She said: “I’m absolutely disgusted with the licence being taken away. “My father-in-law is  and the TV is his leline. He lives in the middle of the countryside, there are no buses at the weekend. The television is his best friend.” Another “Cas Lass”,  year-old Barbara Cotton, said: “We’ve earned it and we deserve it. “We’ve put up with things youngsters wouldn’t put up with. We were deprived – but we won’t be deprived again.” Bob Harris, , a retired electrician, added: “I’ve had a free licence for  years and now they want to take it away. People like me did national service – two years on pittance pay. “It’s outrageous and it’s the thin end of the wedge. Next they’ll have the bus pass, the fuel allowance and then attack the NHS.” Nearly . million old people will lose their hard-won concession in less than a year’s time. Most protesters are in no doubt who the culprits are – Tory ministers who forced this cost-cutting treachery on the Beeb. “The Government should fund the over-s’ TV licences not the BBC,” proclaimed their placards. Hundreds joined the nationwide protests, organised by the National Pensioners Convention. In Glasgow, demonstrators chanted, “BBC, BBC, Keep our Licence Free”. Billy Foster, , reminded the politicians: “Lots of elderly people are really proud and they will refuse to be means tested, and will end up without a TV, which is their only contact with the outside world.” Outside Broadcasting House, in the centre of the capital, Londoner Ian Burleigh insisted “It’s a stealth tax by the Government, hiding behind the skirts of the BBC. “I have great respect for the BBC, but they should have had the guts to stand up to the Government.” The mood over at the Beeb’s northern HQ in Salford, Greater Manchester, was just as vehement. Leonard Mather, an -year-old Korean War veteran, was “disgusted” by the actions of the Corporation and the Government. “Gary Lineker gets paid a fortune for Match of the Day, but they can’t do anything for people who have given so much for their country,” he said.    “The Government should step in and pay the licence fee. If they don’t, the Tories will get slaughtered at the next election as people are very angry.” He has a point. This is electoral dynamite. It’s not just those directly affected. They have sons and daughters, and grandchildren, who are just as passionate as their old folk. This campaign unites the generations. And,he fails to honour his  manesto pledge to keep pensioner benefits, it could well gather enough momentum to shorten betrayer Boris Johnson’s time in No. MPs will debate this injustice on July , after a petition gathered more than , signatures. The Mirror is campaigning to save the free licences, backed by celebs such as Len Goodman and Dame Esther Rantzen. Yesterday, it was the turn of the ordinary British people to have their say and their message to the politicians was loud and clear: “You do this at your peril.”

story: NewsPartner of tragic mum who refused NHS cancer treatment bankrupt after therapy costsKatie Britton-Jordan and her partner, Neil, withdrew money from their pensions to help pay for her alternative treatmentsShareCommentsByGeorge Allen:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsKaties partner, Neil, has admitted he is relying on benefits to get by "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe husband of a mum who died from cancer after rejecting NHS treatment has been left bankrupt by their fight against the disease. Katie Britton-Jordan and her partner, Neil, , spent around £, on a range of alternative treatments, including dendritic cell therapy in Mexico.And Neil, speaking to Derbyshire Live , has now admitted that he now depends on benefits to raise their five-year-old daughter Delilah, and to care for his elderly father. Katie, who died on May , aged , had chosen not to go through conventional chemotherapy and radiotherapy on the NHS when she was diagnosed with triple negative breast cancer in June .Instead, she cut out meat and dairy from her diet, ate only organic foods and took supplements, all of which was already taking a toll on the familyaposs bills. Despite having a mastectomy, by Christmas , the cancer had spread to Katieaposs lymph nodes, liver, lungs and bones and she was in a great deal of discomfort.    When doctors gave Katie just three months to live, the couple withdrew cash from their pensions and raised money from friends and family to travel to Mexico for dendritic cell therapy and other treatments. One friend donated £, from money left to her by her grandfather. Others donated amounts ranging from £ to £,. By the time -year-old Mrs Britton-Jordan arrived in Mexico she was very ill. But her condition improved after the five-week treatment and her lymph nodes had reduced back to their normal size. She felt more comfortable. In total the treatments, which included hyperbolic oxygen chambers, infrared heart treatments, cold laser therapy, blood transfusions, and dendritic cell therapy, among others, cost £,. But it left the couple bankrupt and before long, Mrs Britton-Jordan became severely unwell again. Neil said: She was back in hospital and they said aposthataposs it - thereaposs nothing more we can do for youapos. The couple met at a wellness weekend retreat in Glastonbury back in , when Katie was  and Neil was .    They fell in love, started a jewellery business called Flash Jordan and eventually married in . Their first baby, Tilly Rose, was stillborn. Two years later Katie gave birth to Delilah. It was in June , when Katie was breastfeeding from her right breast that baby Delilah knocked her left breast and she felt an intense pain. Doctors at the Royal Derby Hospital performed a biopsy and scans before delivering the devastating news a few days later. Neil said with hindsight his we would have chosen not to have the biopsy because, he said, stabbing the tumour releases cancerous blood cells into the body. He added: We were told in no uncertain terms that she needed chemotherapy, radiotherapy and a mastectomy, or she was going to die, and that was the only option. We said we wanted to think about our options. We became second-class citizens as soon as we said that. The couple trawled the internet and were faced with a myriad of alternatives.    Katie opted to cut out met and dairy from her diet, as well as purchasing only organic food to eat. After two years the lump in her breast had grown, but the hospital would only perform breast-removal surgeryshe agreed to radiotherapy and chemotherapy too. Mr Jordan was appalled. He said: You canapost put conditions on an operation. Chemotherapy and radiotherapy are both poisons. Instead they travelled to Bradford in April last year and found an NHS surgeon willing to perform the mastectomy. The operation went well but complications followed and Mrs Britton-Jordan ended up hemorrhaging. The plastic porthole devices, known as cannulas, have been used for decades and is a relatively a common practise in industrial farming. The animals are known as cannulated or fistulated cows, and the device allows scientists to optimise and regulate their nutrition by observing the inside of their four stomachs.    However, the animal rights group has launched an online campaign demanding authorities ban the device, adding that the use of cannulas was a symptomatic of the way animals are considered as simple machines at our disposal.
